p: Adult TB/HIV co-disease rates in Eswatini (formally Swaziland) are among some of the highest globally [ 1], and with rapidly evolving drug-resistant strains of TB comes an increased risk for people living with HIV (PLWH). While the country is moving quickly towards UNAIDS treatment targets of 90-90-90 (90% aware of status, 90% on HIV treatment, and 90% virally suppressed), there are concerns that immune compromised individuals remain at a much higher risk of acquiring tuberculosis. Impressive gains in the fight against HIV and TB demonstrate how local systems can coordinate to mitigate international epidemics; however, due to social and behavioral factors and speed of disease progression, screening rates for TB are much lower than necessary, limiting health systemsâ€™ ability to reduce new TB infection [ 2; 3].
